tests.report_sec:
- Insecure: HTTPS not used by default is pretty bad. ( 1.00 rating )
- Content Security Policy is pretty bad. ( 1.00 rating )
- Reporting CSP Certificate Transparency Network Error Logging is good! ( 5.00 rating )
- Referrer Policy is not that good. ( 2.50 rating )
- Subresource Integrity SRI is pretty bad. ( 1.00 rating )
- HTTP headers is ok, with 1 error(s) and 0 warning(s). ( 4.50 rating )
- Cookies is ok, with 12 error(s) and 0 warning(s). ( 1.00 rating )

Insecure: HTTPS not used by default.more_info: wwwravindrarathorecom does not use HTTPS by default

Content Security Policy.more_info: Content Security Policy CSP header not implemented

Reporting CSP Certificate Transparency N.more_info: Reports are not sent to a third-party

Referrer Policy.more_info: Referrer Policy not set This means that the default value strict-origin-when-cross-origin is used which leaks the origin domain when making HTTP-HTTP or HTTPS-HTTPS requests to other domains but the referrer is not sent when making requests to less secure destinations -- ie HTTPS-HTTPS

Subresource Integrity SRI.more_info: Subresource Integrity SRI not implemented but all external resources are loaded over HTTPS

HTTP headers.more_info: To enable these headers youll need to add them to your web server configuration This is a simple change Exactly how you do it depends on what server you use This page developermozillaorg has configuration examples for Apache Nginx and IIS

Cookies.more_info: HttpOnly means that the cookie can only be read by the server and not by JavaScript on the client This can mitigate XSS cross-site scripting attacks
